msDesc.head: Anselm of Canterbury; Honorius Augustodunensis, etc.

msItem.title: De libero arbitrio
msItem.incipit: 1. Quod potestas peccandi non pertineat ad libertatem liberi arbitrii
Discipulus. Quoniam liberum arbitrium videtur repugnare gratię

msItem.note: Pr. F. S. Schmitt, S. Anselmi Cant. Arch. Opera Omnia I, 1946, pp. 205–26.

msItem.title: De concordia praescientiae et praedestinationis
msItem.rubric: De concordia prescientię et predestinationis et gratię Dei cum libero arbitrio
msItem.incipit: De tribus illis questionibus

msItem.note: (in other MSS. the heading is De predestinatione et de libero arbitrio)
msItem.incipit: (fol. 18v) Nunc ergo in eo sperantes
Restat nunc ut de gratia
msItem.explicit: (fol. 32v) quod gratis accepi gratis volui petentibus inpendere.

msItem.note: Pr. Schmitt, op. cit. II, pp. 245–88.
In the space left blank on fol. 32v is an addition in a contemporary hand: it is a short extract on Triumphus, trophaeum, palma, laurea, torques, hedera.
msItem.incipit: Triumphus currus vectio dabatur consulibus pro occisis hostibus.

msItem.title: De cognitione uerae uitae
msItem.incipit: Sapientia dei quę os muti aperuit et asinę rudibili animali humana verba forma retribuit
Fratres. Gratias deo persolvimus cuius dono per te
msItem.note: [MS. Lyell 56, 12th cent., fol. 168, also has this reading].
With an additional passage on fol. 55–6:
msItem.incipit: Fratres. Eia hic ędere sacri ędificii
msItem.note: Inserted between cap. 37–8 of the PL text, pr. J. A. Endres, Honorius Augustodunensis, Kempten, 1906, pp. 138–40, from Munich clm. 22225.

On fol. 33 and 33v a later (15th-cent.) hand has added beati Augustini in red to the red headings. These additions have been crossed out, and a note in another hand of the 15th cent, reads (fol. 33r) videtur hic liber editus per Honorium ex suo in De luminaribus ecclesie et ex stilo; (fol. 33v) Honorii ut videtur ex stilo et ex suo in De luminaribus ecclesie. B. Pez, Thesaurus Anecdotorum Novissimus II, 1721, p. vii, cites this early identification of Honorius as found in our MS., which was then at Melk.

msItem.incipit: Cum tota ecclesia in simbolo de Christo dicat

msItem.rubric: Interrogatio de ascensu et consessu Christi
msItem.incipit: Cum universalis ecclesia corde credat
Cum Iohannes apostolus dicat nolite diligere mundum.
msItem.note: Ends fol. 65v, part of the page left blank. These three quaestiones were pr. from our MS. (then at Melk) by Endres, op. cit., pp. 150–4 and see p. 55.

msItem.title: A collection of quaestiones from the school of Anselm of Laon

msItem.incipit: Potest queri quid sit peccatum et similiter pena peccati
msItem.note: This is the beginning of the collection of sentences pr. Weisweiler in Das Schrifttum der Schule Anselms von Laon und Wilhelm von Champeaux in deutschen Bibliotheken, Beiträge xxxiii. 1–2 (1936), 260–9. In our MS. it is written in the form of sixteen quaestiones; the divisions do not always correspond to those of Weisweiler’s edition and there are textual variants, some of which are closer to the version of this collection incorporated in the Summa Prima rerum origo, printed by Weisweiler, op. cit., p. 174.

msItem.incipit: Si in sanguine passionis filii Dei accepimus remissionem peccatorum
msItem.note: The first of five quaestiones also found in Munich clm. 23440, fol. 84v–85v, and pr. O. Lottin, Nouveaux fragments théologiques de l’école d’Anselme de Laon, R.T.A.M. 13 (1946), pp. 219–20, nos. 322–6.

msItem.incipit: Constat Deum primum hominem fecisse inpassibilem et inmortalem
msItem.note: The first of three quaestiones probably by William of Champeaux, also found together in MS. Heidelberg Univ. Sal. 7. 103, fol. 122–123v. Pr. Lottin, Psychologie et morale v, 1959, pp. 208–10 nos. 258–60.

msItem.incipit: Si mali merito flagellantur, boni quare cum ipsis vel sine ipsis? … Sciendum est quod sunt quidam qui habent intellectum
msItem.note: The part of this quaestio from Sciendum est is found in a number of MSS., including the Heidelberg MS. cit., fol. 123v–124, and is pr. Weisweiler, op. tit., pp. 112–13; Lottin, Psychologie v, p. 243, no. 304.

msItem.title: A collection of sentences on circumcision, redemption, sin, baptism, resurrection, excommunication, the real presence, the death of the body
msItem.note: Clearly related to the four collections pr. Weisweiler, op. tit., pp. 281–358: some of the sentences are the same, others are very similar:

msItem.incipit: Si fides iustificat sicut scriptum est ... In viro tamen et non in muliere
msItem.note: A conflation of two sentences pr. Weisweiler, op. cit., pp. 282–3; 290.

msItem.incipit: Rursus queritur si sancta atque utilis erat circumcisio
msItem.note: Pr. Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 345 (shorter version on pp. 283–4).

msItem.incipit: Omnes quidem peccaverunt et egent gloria Dei ... Queritur cum solo verbo posset hominem redimere
msItem.note: Cf. Weisweiler, op. tit., pp. 299–300.

msItem.incipit: Queritur etiam quę necessitas fuit ut per se ipsum et non per alium.
msItem.note: A version of Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 300.

msItem.incipit: Preterea queritur cur tamdiu distulit ipsam redemptionem? Quia mirabiliter debebat fieri ideo oportuit ut ante a patriarchis et prophetis pronuntiaretur
Queritur si cum in inferno erant, tormenta sustinebant boni cum malis
Queritur ubi dicat apostolus per unum hominem intravit peccatum in mundum
msItem.note: Cf. Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 305.

msItem.incipit: Queritur etiam quod cur illius peccatum transfundatur in omnes posteros
msItem.note: Cf. the short quaestio from MS. Zürich C. 61, pr. Weisweiler, op. cit., p. 163.

msItem.incipit: Concedo quod caro ex came simili materia trahat originem. Sed unde est quod anima cum came corrumpitur
Queritur item cum his qui in matrimonio generant veniale sit generare post baptismum
msItem.note: A version of part of a sentence in Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 296, ll. 3–17.

msItem.incipit: Adhuc queritur cum in baptismate talis homo reddatur qualis fuisset Adam
Adhuc queritur si puero adhuc in utero matris degenti prosit baptismus matris
msItem.note: Pr. Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 305.

msItem.incipit: Cum exaltatus fuero, scilicet resurgendo omnia traham ad me. Queritur hic si corpora sanctorum qui cum domino surrexerunt
Queritur etiam si sicut corporaliter surrexerunt corporaliter etiam ascenderunt
Queritur preterea si latro qui a Christo audire meruit hodie mecum eris in paradyso si statim in cęlesti paradiso locatus fuerit
Queritur si quis prelatus in eadem culpa existens alium excommunicare valeat
Queritur etiam cum illi ligandi vel solvendi haberent officium
Iterum queritur cur iussit fornicatorem tradi sathanę
msItem.note: Cf. Weisweiler, op. tit., p. 298.

msItem.incipit: Queritur quare non ita videatur vere corpus et sanguis Christi vel secundum humanitatis vel secundum deitatis qualitatem
Queritur cum dominus ad reparationem nostram venit quare non ita reparavit corpus sicut et animam
Post mortem Samuelis congregati sunt philistini contra filios Israel

msItem.title: The answer:
msItem.incipit: De qua questione beatę memorię Augustinus episcopus Simplicio Mediolanensi episcopo ita scripsit. Inquiris inquam utrum potuerit malignus spiritus animam iusti excitare
msItem.explicit: (fol. 83v) quamdiu nobis aliquid amplius excogitare et explicare non datur. Hęc sunt quę tunc de phitonissa et Samuele scripsit beatissimus Augustinus.

msItem.note: It is an abbreviation of St. Augustine, De diversis quaestionibus ad Simplicianum, Lib. 11, Q. in: PL 40 col. 142–4.

msItem.author: Honorius Augustodunensis
msItem.title: De anima et de Deo quaedam ex Augustino excerpta sub dialogo exarata

msItem.note: Preceded (fol. 83v) by extracts from Cassiodorus, De anima, caps. 1; 11; iv; v and vi, headed De anima hominis (Cassiodorus added in the margin)
msItem.incipit: Anima hominis proprie dicitur

msItem.note: Honorius’s work (no heading or break in the text):
msItem.incipit: Quę de opere beati Augustini decerpsi studiosis quibus libri desunt stilo tradere curavi. D. Sepius mihi de anima cogitanti
D. Unde est anima? M. A deo
(fol. 94r) Consulenti mihi de anima cęleste oraculum respondit

msItem.note: This work was identified in our MS. when it was at Melk by B. Pez, op. cit., pp. viii-ix; see also Endres, op. cit., pp. 52–5. The work is also in Erlangen University MS. 227, 12th cent., from Heilsbronn, fol. 150v–168v; see H. Fischer, Cat. Hss. Univ. Erlangen I, 1928, p. 274. Now edited by Marie-Odile Garrigues, Recherches Augustiniennes XII (1977), 237–77.

msItem.incipit: Queritur utrum Adam in paradyso beatus fuerit.

msItem.author: Honorius Augustodunensis
msItem.title: Inevitabile
msItem.incipit: Deus condidit rationalem naturam ad vitam. Sed angeli et homines rationales sunt
msItem.explicit: (fol. 110v) Igitur iusticia poscit ut nunquam supplicio careant qui nunquam iusticiam volebant.
msItem.note: This is a version of parts of Honorius Augustodunensis’ Inevitabile in its second, revised form, on which see F. Baeumker, Das Inevitabile des H.A., Beiträge xiii, 6,1914. It is the equivalent of PL 172 col. 1203C2–1205A10; 1206C4–1207A12; 1205A11–D2; 1206A15–C3; 1205D3–1206A14; 1207A13–1209C8; 1217D6–1218A8; 1221B14–C9.

supportDesc.extent: i+116 leaves (fol. 6, 10, 27, 28, 86 are double, fol. i, 111 are flyleaves), 200 118
supportDesc.collation: 1⁸–14⁸, 15⁴ (4 canc.), quires numbered at the end; habet quod decet

layoutDesc.layout: Written space 145 85 : 26 long lines ruled with a hard point

handDesc.handNote: Written in Austria or Germany in the 12th cent.

decoDesc.decoNote: Main initials and headings in red.
Some smaller initials in brown decorated with red dots.
Up to fol. 68r the scribe's marginal captions describing the contents of the text have decorative red frames.

binding.p: 19th-cent. calf binding with flowers and device of crossed keys stamped in gold on the spine.

history.provenance: Formerly belonged to the Abbey of Melk, Austria, and is probably the MS. described as B. 102 in the 1483 Melk catalogue; see Gottlieb, Mittelalt. Bibl. kat. Österreichs 1, 1915, p. 176 1. 33–6. It is inscribed: Monasterii Melicensis and lit. D. 25 on fol. 1, as well as having later library stamps, and on the binding the shelfmark: 850 (P. 40).
Bought by Lyell from E. P. Goldschmidt and Co. in March 1943.
history.acquisition: Chosen as one of the hundred manuscripts bequeathed to the Bodleian by Lyell in 1948.

recordHist.source: Description adapted from A. de la Mare, Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts Bequeathed to the Bodleian Library Oxford by James P. R. Lyell (1971); with additions by Andrew Dunning. Catalogue, p. 176 Catalogue, p. 177 Catalogue, p. 178 Catalogue, p. 179

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Revised from description by Albinia de la Mare.
